https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/94482/ : SUCCESS
Does it use associations or how does it find the PowerWatts?
I've updated the commit message to specify how the association is being used.
Do we need any unit tests for this?
FYI. I'm going to start working on addressing the code review comments of this commit and the other unmerged commits for this same topic.
you implemented more than one property here.  Please document appropriately.  I see at the very least DataSourceUri and Reading
why do we call getSubTree, THEN getObject?  I suspect the subtree call can be removed entirely?
I've restructured the flow which simplifies things. I've updated the commit message with the new flow.

This is getting all sensors for the whole system, not just for this chassis.  As written, this will respond with a PowerWatts object on every chassis.  Do we need a test to verify that behavior doesn't exist in the future?
I've restructured to use the new 'total_power' association for the chassis. I've updated the commit message to show the new flow.

Why are we looking for a specific name of a power sensor?  I realize there is code that does this already in the existing power schemas, but we know from experience that hardcoding specific sensor names is a bad idea, so I don't really want to accept new patches that make that behavior worse.
I've updated to use the new 'total_power' association from the chassis to the sensor. I've updated the commit message with the reference to the commit which added the new association.
We call subtree, then we hardcode an object path?
I've restructured to use the new association, the path is no longer hard-coded. Please see commit message for new flow.
I've modified to use sensor_utils::objectExcerptToJson(). This function builds the DataSourceUri in the standard way.
It's a little odd we have @odata.id and DataSourceURI here.  are you sure that's correct?

You are right, that was not correct. From the schema definition @odata.id should not be here just the DataSourceUri is a defined property for SensorPowerExcerpt.

I've changed to use sensor_utils::objectExcerptToJson() which handles this correctly.
This looks incorrect.  Can you verify that you tested this link produced was correct?
It was not correct. I've tested the link being produced now and the link does connect to the total_power sensor. See commit message for example.
This lambda is 3 tiers deep.  as has been pointed out in the past, please don't write non trivial lambdas.
I've restructured to remove most of the lambdas and created named functions instead.
Thank you for catching this, I've corrected it.
Where is this documented though in PDI?
